channel.title: Storytelling on Pandaqi Tutorials
channel.description: Recent content in Storytelling on Pandaqi Tutorials

item.title: Introduction
item.description: This guide will have a very different structure from any other guide you’ve ever followed. After years of writing and teaching, I’ve learned a simple truth.

item.title: Starting a story
item.description: These two chapters will talk about two things that seem identical, but are quite different. This chapter is about where to get ideas (if you don’t already have one).

item.title: Why we tell stories
item.description: As a general principle, I always start with why?. In most cases, that is the most interesting question and the one that will teach you the most.

item.title: The definition of story
item.description: Okay, so you have an idea, and you’ve answered the questions from the first chapter (about why you’re writing it).

item.title: Continuing a story
item.description: Great! You’ve started a story! You have a strong main character and initial conflict, and you’re off to the races.

item.title: Narrative Structure
item.description: Ideas about how to approach a story are called narrative structure. If you want to find more of these, after doing the rest of this course, look up that term.

item.title: The 3 Act Structure
item.description: Let’s continue with the most common structure (probably). One that is mentioned absolutely everywhere, although I like the “advanced” version more than the simplified one.

item.title: The 4 Act Structure
item.description: Most people admit that the 3 Act Structure is really a 4 Act Structure. These might seem the same at first glance—and they are.

item.title: The Story Circle
item.description: The story circle is usually attributed to famous writer Dan Harmon. It’s a simplified version of what the next chapter is about (the Hero’s Journey).

item.title: The Hero's Journey
item.description: This structure is also called the monomyth. It reappears in many myths from all over the world, from all eras of human history.

item.title: The A, B and C story
item.description: All the narrative structures discussed so far pertain to one storyline. Most stories, however, contain multiple “storylines” or “story threads”.

item.title: The Four Corners of Society
item.description: Over the years, I have noticed that I am more of a “societal” writer. I tend to focus on the whole of society in the worlds I invent, not on just one hero and their journey through it.

item.title: Freytag's Pyramid
item.description: So far, our narrative structures have looked like lines (trending upward) or circles. What if … the structure looked like a pyramid instead?

item.title: Flashbacks
item.description: So far, our narrative structures have been linear. This is fine, because almost all stories are linear. We simply start when the story becomes interesting, follow the hero through time (chronologically), then end when the story is over.

item.title: Setup & Payoff
item.description: This isn’t necessarily a narrative structure. It’s a very simple idea that you’ll probably use many times in any story you write.

item.title: Plot Twists
item.description: Many writers have heard about the infamous “mystery boxes” from J.J. Abrams. They also know countless examples of stories that thought they were being clever by adding a big “plot twist” or “surprise revelation”, but were actually being dumb and ruining their own story.

item.title: Mystery Boxes
item.description: Previous chapter talked about plot twists and introduced the idea of “surprising readers” … in the wrong way. This chapter talks more about mysteries and revelations.

item.title: In Media Res
item.description: I remember being taught the concept of “in media res” at elementary school. Unfortunately, it was taught badly. Many people know the word, but have a somewhat useless understanding of the concept.

item.title: Dialogue Deep Dive
item.description: When I submitted my first story to a publisher, I received the feedback that there was way too much dialogue.

item.title: Description Deep Dive
item.description: Previous chapter was all about dialogue. This one will be about the other thing you can do with your writing: description.

item.title: Fichtean Curve
item.description: The Fichtean curve is a slight variation on the 3 Act Structure, which is very common in fantasy and sci-fi novels, or longer “adventure” stories in general.

item.title: Seven-Point Story Structure
item.description: I’ve moved this structure near the end of the course. Not because it’s terribly difficult—I mean, you already know it only has seven points—but because I never knew what to make of it.

item.title: Archetypes
item.description: We’ve done many chapters with structures that mostly determine your plot. So let’s do another challenge that’s all about character!

item.title: Personality Test
item.description: Another chapter to help you write amazing characters. There’s this personality test that is used in professional settings because its results are quite accurate and useful.

item.title: Interactive Stories
item.description: Besides being a writer, I am a game developer. That’s why I’ve always had an interest in “interactive stories”.

item.title: Different Lenses: Tone
item.description: So far, we’ve been writing stories in the traditional way. There’s a narrator, it describes the events and the dialogue, and maybe there’s a hint of “writing style” or personality.

item.title: Different Lenses: Media
item.description: As promised, this chapter is about different (general) ways in which you can tell a story. I am very interested in this and will probably do more of it in the future.

item.title: The Four Seasons
item.description: This isn’t necessarily a structure, but more of a challenge based on some interesting ideas. We’re nearing the end of this course, which means I think you’re ready for longer and more complicated ideas.

item.title: Beat Sheet
item.description: Maybe you thought that the narrative structures discussed thus far were too limiting for your creativity. Well, then I have bad news for you.

item.title: The Final Boss
item.description: Honestly, this course could go on and on. There are infinitely many ideas about what a story should look like, how you could tell it, from big frameworks to tiny tips that might help in specific scenes.

item.title: Finishing a Story
item.description: You’ve written the first version of your story. (Or you’re ~80% through that first draft.) What are some tips for finishing a story?

item.title: Mindset
item.description: Writing stories is hard. It’s a really complex task that requires you to imagine whole worlds, characters, and sequences of events from nothing.

item.title: Conclusion
item.description: Congratulations! You have reached the end of the storytelling course. If you followed along, you’ll have written more than 20 unique (short) stories.
